Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Annual Dues Support for IASC and SCAR 2017-2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical:
U.S. support for International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) provides opportunities for U.S. scientists to exchange ideas and develop research partnerships with colleagues in other countries. For early career scientists these organizations offer a forum to expand research interests and develop professional connections. SCAR and IASC's policy advisory activities help ensure that important policy decisions about managing and protecting these regions are based on sound scientific assessment. International collaboration through SCAR and IASC's interdisciplinary, international research activities allows the U.S. to accomplish scientific objectives that would be impossible for single investigators, programs, or countries to do alone and provides opportunities for U.S. scientists that would not otherwise be available.

Technical:
The Polar Research Board (PRB) of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences serves as the U.S. National Committee to two international organizations: the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC), and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR). IASC encourages and facilitates cooperation in all aspects of Arctic research and in all areas of the Arctic region, provides scientific input to the Arctic Council and other international policy organizations, and provides seed money to support international science development. SCAR helps lead the international Antarctic science community by implementing new research initiatives, identifying emerging scientific themes, promoting international cooperation and partnerships, and providing scientific advice to the Parties to the Antarctic Treaty and others on issues related to the management and protection of the Antarctic region and the Southern Ocean. The U.S. dues requested leverage in-kind contributions from countries around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Polar Research Board (PRB) of the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine serves as the U.S. National Committee to two international nongovernmental polar science organizations: the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR).  NSF support of U.S. annual dues for these organizations is crucially important for advancing opportunities and interests of the U.S. polar research community, and for assuring continued progress in international-level research and assessment.

 

IASC [http://www.iasc.info/] is a non-governmental, international scientific organization with a mission to encourage and facilitate cooperation in Arctic research. IASC promotes and supports leading-edge multi-disciplinary research to foster greater scientific understanding of the Arctic region and its role in the Earth system. IASC has 23 member countries.  Some key IASC activities during this report period include:

  • The Arctic Science Summit Week (ASSW) an annual gathering of international organizations engaged in supporting and facilitating Arctic research, to foster international coordination, collaboration and cooperation in all fields of Arctic science. In odd numbered years ASSW also includes an associated science symposium and in even number years it includes the Arctic Observing Summit.  
  • Initiatives of IASC’s main scientific Working Groups: Atmosphere, Cryosphere, Marine, Social and Human, and Terrestrial;  and crosscutting science initiatives that involve multiple working groups.
  • The Arctic Data Committee, which promotes and facilitates international collaboration towards the goal of free, ethically open, sustained and timely access to Arctic data through useful, usable, and interoperable systems.
  • The Sustaining Arctic Observing Networks (SAON), which support development of multinational engagement for sustained and coordinated pan-Arctic observing and data sharing. 
  • The IASC Fellowship Program, which helps foster participation of early career researchers in the organization of IASC workshops, science planning activities and research programs.
  • International Science Initiative in the Russian Arctic (ISIRA), an international cooperative initiative to assist Arctic science and sustainable development in the Russian Arctic.
  • IASC Medals, which are awarded in recognition of exceptional and sustained contributions to the understanding of the Arctic.

 

SCAR [http://www.scar.org/] initiates, promotes and coordinates scientific research in Antarctica. SCAR also provides international, independent scientific advice to the Antarctic Treaty system and other bodies. SCAR has 32 full member countries and 12 associate members.  Some key SCAR activities during this report period include:

  • SCAR Biennial Meetings, which include business meetings of SCAR’s many planning groups, the Delegates meeting, and an Open Science Conference (OSC).   
  • The SCAR Biology Symposium and Antarctic Earth Sciences Symposium, each held every four years.
  • The SCAR Early Career Fellowship Programme for PhD students (or those who recently completed a PhD), to undertake research at major international laboratories, field facilities, and/or institutes in or operated by SCAR member countries.
  • The SCAR Visiting Professor Scheme, which offers mid- to late-career scientists and academics the opportunity to undertake a short term visit to another SCAR member country to provide training and mentoring.
  • SCAR's Scientific Groups—Geosciences, Life Sciences, Physical Sciences, which play a central role within SCAR, to share information on research being conducted by national Antarctic programs, to identify areas where current research is lacking, to coordinate proposals for future research among national programs, and to form Action Groups and Expert Groups to advance exploration of specific research topics.
  • Scientific Research Programmes (SRPs) are the main focus of SCAR’s international scientific coordination. These Programmes typically have a 6-8 year lifetime. The current set will end in 2020, and planning for the next generation of programmes is underway.
